description.text: OpenSCAD file to design nut-capture boxes.  Specify bolt size, nut size, wall thickness, etc.

Edit the top of the file to set the size of the threaded rod and nut.  You may specify "easing" parameters which will enlarge the openings slightly to allow ease of insertion.  Keep the easing small, especially for small nuts/bolts, or the thing may become so sloppy-fitting to no longer hold the nut from spinning.

comments.text: Mcmaster's website seems to be a pretty good place to get nut/bolt dimensions. If you click on a part number for a bolt/nut and go to the CAD section, it will give the dimensions to you.

description.text:
This part holds LEDs so that you can bend their leads to fit into a wedge base light bulb socket. I designed it to work with Adafruit's Massive Arcade Button so that you could add super bright LEDs to its switch.

Make sure that you're applying the correct resistor for the LEDs and supply voltage that you use. This one's nice and simple. http://ledcalc.com/ The load resistor doesn't fit in the socket, so put it on the wiring between your LED and the voltage source.

Created with DesignSpark Mechanical, RSDOC source file is included.

Notes:

They're tiny, so printing multiple copies at the same time helps them turn out without melting.

This is a collage of Venus of Willlendorf, by 3Dmigos and Simple Buckles, by keyjay. I chose to mash the Venus, an ancient fertility goddess representation, with the functional object that holds up one's pants. I find it humorous to both glorify and poke fun at the importance of this historical sculpture by mashing it with a belt buckle that is usually associated with machismo personas. Cowboys, superheroes, and other masculine characters come to mind when thinking of the over-exaggerated belt buckle. I made a belt buckle that both objectifies and celebrates this feminine fertility object.

title: V3 Micro Switch â€“ OpenSCAD Parametric Model

description.text: Since in needed one of these for a limit switch holder I am designing I modelled a V3 micro switch in openSCAD. The model is parametric so you can select which type of arm you need (except for simulated roller, as I cant work out how to make arcs easily in SCAD) or enter the parameters for your own.

To use in your own model call, use ; v3_micro_switch(type = 1); Type
1 = button
2 = long roller
3 = short roller
4 = long lever

title: MakerFarm i3v 12" BLTouch Adjustable Height Mount

description.text:
Special Note : This part is not to be printed forsale or for anyone / company to profit from the design. This part is not to be included in the design of a kit which is for the marketplace.

This part is for the side of the carriage to mount a BLTouch Z-probe sensor.. I can now confirm I am using this design tested on a Makerfarm i3v 12". The adjustable height range is awesome as it lets you tune to your specific printer as all nozzle heights are slightly different based on how much you tighten the nozzle to the hotend...

Works flawlessly. I used metric 3mm bolts, nuts and flat washers to connect the pieces together. I also printed in PLA as it is not close to the hot end and will never be close to it so no harm in using PLA.

This footprint is slightly more than a servo arm, but there is much less moving parts and the results are repeatable.

I'm in no way affiliated or employed by Snap, Inc. (AKA-Snapchat).

This design was released on 9/23/2016 and I chose to copy the design of the frame so that I could create my own version of "Spectacles" using a Raspberry Pi Zero. This uses my own measurements and is designed from scratch using Fusion 360.

It's a work in progress, and I will continue to post updates. Sharing your print is the best way to thank me for the design. Have fun!

A printed spur gear driven extruder for Mendel or Darwin.

Construction and testing details on the RepRap wiki here:
http://objects.reprap.org/wiki/Development:Geared_Nema17_Extruder This is a new extruder design based on Adrian\'s geared nema 14 extruder, with some ideas from Nophead\'s extruders. During testing it produced over 16 kg of pulling force on the filament. Hot end development is still ongoing, but it should plug and play with any existing 16 mm thermal breaks.

comments.text: I couldn't get the MK5 drive gear easily in Canada, plus the smaller diameter (6.3 mm in my case) increases the filament drive force and resolution.  And, with PLA at least, I get more than enough grip on the filament.  16 kg of pull works out to about 3600 PSI - that's at lot of pressure; I think the hot end will fail before you get that high.

comments.text: I dont see also, what should I put between the two part (extruder block and extruder idler block).
comments.author: laszlo

comments.text: Laszlo, the blind hole is intentional, you just drill it out before assembly.  I added in a 1 mm membrane across that hole to allow Skeinforge's bridging code to take care of the overhanging shoulder on the lower bearing mount.  Without it, the overhang will sag when printed on a Reprap, but with it, the overhang prints fine.

description.text:
LM8UU y-carriage for Orca 0.2, created with OpenSCAD. Printed and tested. Uses:
  • "Lm8uu Y axis Holder" Created by
    GregFrost: thingiverse.com/thing:9871

• Print
  • Clean. If printed with pads, remove pads
  • Insert LM8UU, if printed with PLA it may be necessary to warm the holder to avoid breakage.
    (3a. Optional, but recommended: Put a little bit of glue under each LM8UU before insertion)
  • Remove old y-carriage
  • Insert new y-carriage, attach base plate, longer screws may be necessary, 4xM4x35 should fit.
    • The carriage has the same height as the original y-carriage. Comments/suggestions are appreciated.

description.text: This is a percussion instrument.  I had a similar one which I lost and couldn't find a suitable replacement.  I got some great sounds with bb's so far.  I'll try lentils tomorrow for a softer tone.

Without burning yourself, throw in some bb's or lentils or seeds or anything you can think of halfway into the build. The rest of the print will seal them inside forever!
Experiment with different materials for different sounds!

print_settings.Notes:: I recommend to use PLA for everything, as you can see the cap and aimer pieces fits in slots and are print-in-place pieces, with ABS, the joints always breaks when attempting to rotate them.

description.text:
LIKE AND SHARE!!!

EDIT6: So... I decided it was too much of a hassle for me to look for the measurements myself for every phone I was asked to customize, therefore, I added an image with the measurements I need to do this. Please add these data so I can customize your case fast. Here is the list of what I need:
"phone_thick"=
"phone_length"=
"phone_width" =
"cam_x" =
"cam_y" =
"cam_length" =
"cam_width" =
"rigthHole_y" =
"rigthHole_length"=
"leftHole_y"=
"leftHole_length"=
"jack_x" =
"jack_z" =
If it’s not clear enough please leave a comment with your question.

EDIT5: Added 5 more models (Moto G4/G4plus, Nexus6, Zenfone3 and HTCM8) I dont know if they will fir propperly... please feel free to give me any feed back. Sorry IF I took too long... was on my vacations.

EDIT4: Added 1 new model (HTC E8). Now... there wasn't any 3d model online of this phone, so, I'm not sure about the accuracy of the side buttons and camera location... please review these before printing and tell if I should change anything.

EDIT3: Addet 3 new models (LG G3, Galaxy S7 (non edge) and Galaxy Note II )

EDIT2: Fixed iphone 5s thickness... I was off by around 1mm and didn't fit, I changed this and now it should work. If any of you notice that the measures of your model are off or have any suggestion please make it in the comment section and I'll try to fix it ASAP. Sorry, my bad :(

EDIT: Added 3 new models (Iphone 5c, Nexus 5X and Regular Note 3)

3D printed Pokedex Case with aimer and team logo.

Ask me for more phone models, I'll try to add it ASAP!!

Every phone has 3 pieces of their own and are the following:

  • "PhoneName"Cap
  • "PhoneName"Aimer
  • "PhoneName"Body
    Download those 3 and for the finishing details there are the other pieces (that works on every model) that you can print in other colors so it looks cooler.

You can also add the team logo in front of the case (see pics). I've uploaded the 3 team logos for 2-color print.

Available Models:

  • Iphone 5s (fixed)
  • Iphone 5c
  • Iphone 6
  • Galaxy Note 2
  • Galaxy Note 3
  • Galaxy Note 3 Neo
  • Galaxy S7 (non edge)
  • Galaxy S7 Edge
  • Galaxy J7
  • Moto X2
  • Moto G2
  • Moto G4/G4 PLus
  • Zenfone 2
  • Zenfone 3
  • Xperia ZQ/ZL
  • Nexus 5X
  • Nexus 6
  • LG G3
  • HTC E8
  • HTC M8

This case only adds 4mm on the sides and 2mm in the front/back, it won't leave your phone as a huge monstrosity (The Iphone 5S version is the best, so tiny and cute haha) and in some models leaves the phone with access to all side buttons and even the audio jack.

Printer:

Sethi3D AiP A3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

20%

Notes:

When printing the body part, remember to add support (on Repetier with Silc3r the support that works better for me is "Pillars", as seen in 2nd pic).

I recommend to use PLA for everything, as you can see the cap and aimer pieces fits in slots and are print-in-place pieces, with ABS, the joints always breaks when attempting to rotate them.
After print you can glue the other pieces printed in other color (see pics). I glued them with SuperBonder it works just fine.

title: San Francisco Bay Bridge - Western Span

description.text: This is a 3D model of the western span of the San Francisco Bay Bridge I designed in OpenSCAD to be 3D printed. All of the smaller features such as the cabling and cross-beam supports have been made so as to be substantial enough to be picked up when sliced for printing (My early efforts had the smaller details simply disappear when sliced).

RepRap

Printer:

Kossel Mini

No

.4mm

100%

description.text:
Note: This is incomplete and untested - I am yet to finish designing the left motor/idler part and a suitable print fan. Please post comments / suggestions.

This is a work in progress of a dual x-carriage system for the BigBox 3D printer. I will add some photos of the assembled parts shortly. Once I have finalised an initial version I will add the source files.

You will need some additional hardware:

GT2 belts
1x 20-tooth pulley
2x F-604-ZZ bearings
1x Stepper driver
1x Stepper motor (I am using these for X0/1 and E0/1 - http://www.omc-stepperonline.com/nema-17-bipolar-step-motor-29v-07a-18ncm255ozin-17hs100704s-p-260.html)
Various screws, nuts and washers.

Revision 27/09/2016 @ 21:44

  • Added cable supports to the top clamp plates for the motor, thermistor, heater cartridge and hot end fan cables.

  • Added left motor/idler part. I haven't test printed this, I suspect that there may be an issue with the idler printing properly.
  • Added y-min endstop mount point to right mount/idler part.

  • Modified left motor/idler to print better

remixed_from.author: monnerby
remixed_from.title: InMoov hand dual track servo pulleys

title: InMoov Finger Starter (including a servo-safer option)

description.text:
Hello InMoov Starters,

This Finger Starter project is a Remix from different "Things".

  • First: it's a redesign from Gaël's his Finger Starter kit.
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:67709
  • Second: is a combination from Mats Servo double track Pulley.
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1074604
  • Third: I'm using my first servo pulley design...
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1052776

The difference between Gaël's design and my, this one is a bit longer to get a option to use a spring in line.
This spring gives the option to Safe the servo mechanical way when the Finger is pulling.
With the spring it's a option to use smaller servo's like the CS238MG.
These are strong enough and the total weights are half of the weight from a standard servo !
This is a nice future because each extra weight in the InMoov arm is to much !

I've included two different size of pulley's.
(both are the same, only the cave to mount the pulley to the servo is different.)
CS238MG servo's are using M2.5 ! and a standard servo is M3.
Hitec/Futaba spline 25 teeth based.

These pulley's are working like Mats double track pulley's.
Only I'm using a single track and my pulley's are not symmetric !
The reason why I use these not symmetric setup, is to get a lower power use from the servo.
When the Finger is getting closer and closer, the pulley is getting smaller and smaller....
This means, when the finger is closed, the pulley is small and this gives a better power use form a servo.
Here a first video without the spring: (more video's will follow later)
https://youtu.be/HaEzM8pp8b0

During a quick test, the CS238MG servo was using a maximum current from 6mA, even when I'm holding down the finger !
So the servo-safer works :-)

To make this Finger Starter kit complete, you will need these FingerIndex files from Gaël:
http://www.thingiverse.com/download:1027899
For the basic assembling info, please check the website from Gaël:
http://inmoov.fr/finger-starter/

To mount a standard servo or the CS238MG servo-adapter, I've used four M4 x 12mm screws.
The SC238MG servo is mounted with two M3 x 8mm screws.
The Arduino is mounted with M3 x 6mm screws.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

35%

Notes:

The Finger_Starter_Spring STL can be printed with a resolution from 0.15mm and with a 30% infill.

All parts we need... Optional spring (mechanical servo-safer) First parts we need... Pull the rope sideway... Push both pulley parts together... To keep the rope on place, just use the screw for a moment... Next step is mounting the pulley to the servo... Make sure the servo is set to his finger open position ! (Counter-Clockwise) The easiest way, is to use the "Knob" servo sketch: (or check MyRobotLab)

/*
Controlling a servo position using a potentiometer (variable resistor)
by Michal Rinott http://people.interaction-ivrea.it/m.rinott

modified on 8 Nov 2013
by Scott Fitzgerald
http://www.arduino.cc/en/Tutorial/Knob
*/

include

Servo myservo; // create servo object to control a servo

int potpin = 0; // analog pin used to connect the potentiometer
int val; // variable to read the value from the analog pin

void setup() {
myservo.attach(3); // attaches the servo on pin 3 to the servo object
}

void loop() {
val = analogRead(potpin); // reads the value of the potentiometer (value between 0 and 1023)
val = map(val, 0, 1023, 0, 180); // scale it to use it with the servo (value between 0 and 180)
myservo.write(val); // sets the servo position according to the scaled value
delay(15); // waits for the servo to get there
}

When the pulley is on place, it looks like this... Next steps are to ad the finger... Part 1... Part 2... Part 3... Tie a knot in both ropes with enough extra lenght (which we need at the pulley side !) Cut the rope and pull the rope tight and use for each rope a M3 screw with a ring to lock them...

author: MdG_NL

description.text:
This is a lightpainting tool created for the photokina 2016. I assembled a selection of these and gave them to the visitors of the fair to introduce them to the world of lightpainting.
It is designed to be very easy to use and simple to build.

To assemble the tool you need:

  • a pvc pipe with 14mm diameter usually used to put cables in a wall
  • 5 5mm LEDs of wanted colors
  • some wires
  • a switch
  • a button cell battery (CR2032)
  • paint
  • a rubber band
  • (maybe a resistor)

Put the LEDs in the led chamber and wire them together in parallel. Keep in mind that different colors might habe different voltage needs and you have to add a resistor.
Paint the pipe black, so it doesn't catch the light.
Mark the middle with the rubber band, so you can find it in the dark.
Cut a hole in the pipe about two hands away from the middle to fit the switch.
Drag two wires along the pipe to solder them to the switch and tape the switch to in the hole.
Assemble the head using the ends of the wires to create the contacts in the battery chamber.
Once assembled hold the pipe in the middle and put the counterweight at the other end, but don't put it in all the way yet. Depending on the material the counterweight should have about the correct weight to balance the pipe. If it is not balanced put a little sand into the counterweight until it is. Put the plug in the counterweight and add it to the pipe.
Take a look at the assembly pictures for help.

To create an orb set up a camera on a tripod and start a long exposure. Put a glowstick on the ground somewhere in front of the camera and stand close ti it. Hold the pipe exactly above the glowstick and start to turn it around its middle. Now walk in small steps around the glowstick making sure you always hold the pipe right above it. Once you complete a full circle switch of the LEDs and stop your exposure. You should have a great light-ball now like in the example pictures.

Ideal to be use in wargames. Designed to be printed in once piece with no support but could be tricky depending on your printer.
This is part of a serie of 8 Barricade pieces (4 smalls, 4 larges).

title: Zach Fair Buster Sword
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is The Buster sword wielded by Zach Fair. The main protagonist in Final Fantasy 7 Crisis core, as i was designing this i used actual measurements to make it too scale so at the very least the length and thickness of the blade hilt and handle are all the same.

This was a request by quincydon17 for the hilt of the sword. I went ahead and finished the rest of the sword and made the hilt and sword both separate and then one model where they are fused together.

If there are any other requests for a prop or item of any sort send me a message and i will see what i can do.

Happy Printing.

Step one Research

As i was looking into making this sword i wanted to make sure that i had it done right so i started looking up the dimensions for the sword in game and once i found them i started to gather pictures and formulate a plan on how i would start and finish the project.

Step 2 Mock up

Once i had a base idea i began to make the base models that i would use for the blade and the hilt. i started with just one solid outline and then would start cutting away at the part and adding details and contours to it to make it pop with the detail i strive for in all of my parts.

Starting with the just the hilt I worked on it to near completion and then i started to make the blade

Step 3 Final step

after working out the detail on the hilt i started to work on the blade. the blade was considerably easier due to the lack of detail that is on it. there was a small snag when putting the edge on the blade i noticed that at the top it tappers off to a point instead of remaining thick the whole length of the tapper so what turned out to be an easy later on was painstaking aggravation, where I went to bed and thought out the process for the morning.

after finishing the blade i fit the two together and called it good.

title: Net Ball - Fully Functional PokeBall with Button and Hinge

description.text:
Barnacules printed this PokeBall go check out his video! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8SkTL3rZV00

WARNING!

  • This is work in progress, I am yet to sucessfully print the 'Net' part of the lid but feel free to have a go and provide any feedback, best of luck!

UPDATE: 27th September 2016

  • Added a 3mm Hinge Pin file for those who wish to use the 3mm hinge for a stronger hinge but have a 1.75mm filament printer. Can also be used if you would rather print a pin to the right shape rather than use filament.

DESCRIPTION

Fully functional NetBall made to be an exact replica of the real thing! Uses only 3D printed parts and super glue yet has fully functional hinge and button which presses in and unlocks a catch to allow you to open it, using the flex in the plastic to act as a spring. Hinge opens to 90 degrees and stops like the real thing and does not stick out the back so cannot be seen, also just like the real thing. The button also hides its own mechanism from view adding to the authenticity. Parts have notches and grooves to ensure perfect alignment while glueing allowing you to have a perfect model with ease.

I believe this to be the most accurate and easy to print NetBall you can make with a 3D printer so print your own and get catching Pokemon! Even the stand looks like a PokeBall from above.

Other PokeBall lids available and more coming soon including (see picture):
PokeBall - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1615753
Great Ball - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1677042
Ultra Ball - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1675718
Master Ball - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1794489
Timer Ball - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1794410
Quick Ball
Heavy Ball
Luxury Ball
Premier Ball
Nest Ball

So check back regularly to get them as they come out and if you have a favourite not on the list let me know and I will try my best to get it designed and made as fast as I can!

PRINTING INSTRUCTIONS

Do not use a raft as parts are not prone to warping and make clean up harder, I do use a brim however to aid adhesion.

Instructions as follows:

Print all parts with support touching build plate.
Remove support, however the PokeBall has been designed to hide all supported surfaces, so they should be hidden from view so a smooth finish is not vital for it to look good.
Print the lids with the dome side up like an igloo.
Print the 'Inner Shells' the other way up like a bowl.
Print the 'Button' with the flat surface on the build plate.
Use 3mm or 1.75mm filament as a hinge pin and shape to fit smoothly as in the pictures so it follows the same curve as the back of the ball.
Do a dry fit of all the parts.
Super glue the lids to their respective 'Inner Shells'.
Place the 'Button' inside the 'Outer Button Smaller' with the two bumps positioned downwards to fit into the 'Inner Shell Bottom' and super glue the 'Outer Button Smaller' to the 'Inner Shell Top' being careful not to glue the 'Inner Button' in place as it must be able to be pressed.
Insert the hinge pin attaching the two halves together and glue in place also taking care not to glue the hinge in a fixed position.
You will need:

1x Net Ball Lid Base
1x Net Ball Net
1x White Lid
1x Inner Shell Top (choose filament size and with or without support)
1x Inner Shell Bottom (choose filament size and with or without support)
1x Button
1x Outer Button Smaller
1x Stand (optional)
Super Glue
If you have problems with supports or printing let me know and I will do what I can to help. The tolerances are also quite tight as this works on my printer, let me know if you have problems with this.

Happy Printing and Go Catch Them All!

description.text:
On my quest to live sustainable I realised that I don't want to miss out my hot shower in the morning. So I built this flow restrictor that fits into the screw connector part of my shower.
The upper outer diameter is 10mm and the lower outer diameter is kind of 7mm.
I only found flat inlets here on thingiverse so I thought I could design something that doesn't render the black rubber seal useless.

  • It has a perfect fit: You can press it in by hand and remove it still with your leatherman
  • The hole is quite small with 2mm. So I suggest to use a 2-4mm drill to adjust the hole to your need. Or you can use the 3D Builder from Microsoft to subtract a cylinder shape from my part. My favorite setting was achieved with a 2mm drill.
  • The part should be built with support. The standard support by slic3r did the job
  • Since it is a very small part it is a good idea to apply active cooling while printing
  • Being a Thingiverse thing I had to put the T on it

This thing is a remix of this one: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:784247 (the STL called MK9_i3_wide_right.stl). We need 3 of those for a diamond hotend.

I had problems with the original design: The bowden holder holes have the same diameter than the thread of the holder. The holders eventually goes out of their hole and cannot be screwed again. This phenomena is enhanced by the heat of the motors on this plastic part.

Then I enhanced it a bit by extruding the hole from the design to avoid motors heat, but most important is that I reduced the hole diameter to be a little bit smaller than the bowden holders thread diameter.

I printed it in ABS for temperature resistance with the diamond hothend just for the fun.

title: Prusa i3 MK2 Filament spool holder for quick and easy swapping(ORIGINAL PRUSA I3 MK2)

description.text:
A new design for the spool holder of the ORIGINAL PRUSA I3 MK2 3D PRINTER. For quick and easy swapping. Printed with no suports!
A video can be found here: https://youtu.be/IOQ6q4xmlrQ

UPDATE

Notch added to prevent breaking of the spool holder arm when putting it on the frame.

Clearances between the two spindle parts are increased. So no sanding should be required.

Because some people don't have access to the right size of pvc pipe. I added a new optional design for the spindle called "Spool_Holder_Spindle_Part1 and Spool_Holder_Spindle_Part2". That makes the design completely 3D printable without any need for additional hardware

It consist of 4 printed parts and one smal piece of pvc pipe. The PVC tube has a diameter of 20 mm and is 10cm long.
If you can't find any 20mm PVC pipe. There is also an 25mm version available by mickgalt at this link: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2008183

The clearance between the PVC pipe and caps may be too large or too small. This is due to the fluctuating inner diameter of various manufacturers of PVC pipes. But some 2 part epoxy can fix that.

Note: After printing, the parts need to be cleaned up by cutting the overhanging material away.

Printer:

ORIGINAL PRUSA I3 MK2 3D PRINTER

title: E3Dv6 plus Fan mount for MP Mini

description.text:
Updated v3 Fan shroud has been modified to better direct the air flow to the print.

Lasted fan for the E3Dv6 on a Monoprice Mini. The Fan shroud is designed to fit in an area of 4.5mm between the print bed and the base of the hot end. Also 53.25 mm from the base of the front lock to the print bed. Depending on the nozzle and if you have an original E3Dv6 these measurement may need to be adjusted. A step file has been supplied so you can modify if needed.

Screws are #6x32

comments.text: I like this design, it is very good. Just a thought, could you make the output of the fan go around the hot end nozzle in a full circle? It would make a more even cooling on the plastic.
comments.author: pcdeni

comments.text: That was my original thought but I rant into space issues at the back side. This could probably do with a redesign with a larger vent with a bigger inner diameter and tube. My earliest design that extends dramatically forward is one sided but provides amazing part cooling. I've made clean 90 mm bridges with that one. It is just questionable with the stresses it might cause to the printer,
comments.author: pcdeni

comments.text:
Space issues? What was causing the space issue?
Still, can I ask you to modify the design in which the flat bottom part goes around the nozzle in a circle?
comments.author: ImChris

comments.text: This is my favorite part cooling fan design so far. I have a question though: In the photo, it looks like the output of the fan is blowing directly onto the upper part of the nozzle near the hot end. Wouldn't you want to angle the air stream down slightly so air hits the tip of the nozzle and below? This would be to reduce cooling of the hotend while increasing cooling of the melted plastic. It may just be the angle of the photo you took.

title: Raspberry Pi camera module afocal telescope mount

description.text:
Raspberry Pi Camera Module Mount for Afocal Astrophotography.

Design goal for the mount was to facilitate fine movement of the Raspberry Pi camera along 5 degrees of freedom in front of a telescope eyepiece:

  • translations along both axes perpendicular to viewing direction,
  • translations along the axis of the viewing direction and
  • rotations around both axes perpendicular to viewing direction.

Design Compatibility Notes

Mount was designed to be used with 1.25" eyepieces, but can be adapted to other diameters.

Several parts were designed to fit bolts and nuts available at my locale.
Appropriate holes should be adjusted accordingly for use with bolts and nuts of other dimensions prior to printing. Blender file is included amongst the downloads for that purpose.
Affected parts are:

  • fastener-mandibula, where holes were made to fit M5 nuts,
  • fastener-railing, where ducts were made to fit M5 nuts,
  • adjuster-casing-front, where sockets were made to fit M5 nuts,
  • camera-sitting-back, where holes were made to fit M3 nuts and
  • bolt knobs, that were designed to fit bolts with flat, slotted heads.

Assembly instructions

Some assembly is required after printing.
In addition to the printed parts, the final assembly requires:

  • 10 5mm x 3cm bolts with corresponding M5 nuts,
  • 4 3mm x 3cm bolts with corresponding M3 nuts,
  • small elastic bands or elastic cord and
  • strips of rubber.
All parts were designed and modeled in FreeCAD. They were then exported to Blender, where they were cleaned, scaled, rearranged and exported to final .obj and .stl files.

description.text:
[EN] V1 : the prototype

I like taking pictures with a fish-eye effect. But as I am a dslr user, the gopro is sometimes to small in my opinion to be held comfortably. So here comes this project I had in mind since a few times.

Nota bene : Here is my first attempt in designing a 3D thing. The housing is working with my Hero3, but many little things will be improved. Feel free to suggest :D

Improvements to come :

  • Button for wifi
  • Button for on/off and modes
  • Lens protection, without reducing the angle of view
  • Lock the back of the camera
  • Make it wider, my fingers can actually be seen on the extreme right of pictures.
  • Add a tripod hole
  • Add a flash cold shoe
  • Find a cool name !

[FR] V1 : le proto

Pourquoi cette chose ? En plus de l'usage classique d'une gopro, j'aime bien l'utiliser occasionnellement en mode photo fish-eye. Sauf qu'étant habitué à utiliser des appareils plus gros, je trouvais la gopro vraiment peu confortable à l'usage. Donc ... voilà ! :D

Nota bene : je débute tout juste en 3D, des choses sont bien sur à améliorer et le seront certainement. Toute suggestion est la bienvenue :D

J'ai en tête :

  • Un bouton pour activer le wifi
  • Mettre un bouton devant le sélecteur de modes
  • Trouver un moyen ingénieux de protéger la lentille sans rétrecir l'angle de prise de vue.
  • Vérouiller l'arrière de l'appareil
  • Augmenter les dimensions du boitier, actuellement je vois très légèrement mes doigts sur le bord droit de l'image
  • Ajouter un pas-de-vis pour trépied

title: Timer Ball - Fully Functional PokeBall with Button and Hinge

description.text:
Barnacules printed this PokeBall go check out his video! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8SkTL3rZV00

WARNING!

  • This is work in progress, I have not yet printed this and it may be difficult but best of luck to those who try!

UPDATE: 27th September 2016

  • Added a 3mm Hinge Pin file for those who wish to use the 3mm hinge for a stronger hinge but have a 1.75mm filament printer. Can also be used if you would rather print a pin to the right shape rather than use filament.

DESCRIPTION

Fully functional TimerBall made to be an exact replica of the real thing! Uses only 3D printed parts and super glue yet has fully functional hinge and button which presses in and unlocks a catch to allow you to open it, using the flex in the plastic to act as a spring. Hinge opens to 90 degrees and stops like the real thing and does not stick out the back so cannot be seen, also just like the real thing. The button also hides its own mechanism from view adding to the authenticity. Parts have notches and grooves to ensure perfect alignment while glueing allowing you to have a perfect model with ease.

I believe this to be the most accurate and easy to print TimerBall you can make with a 3D printer so print your own and get catching Pokemon! Even the stand looks like a PokeBall from above.

Other PokeBall lids available and more coming soon including (see picture):
PokeBall - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1615753
Great Ball - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1677042
Ultra Ball - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1675718
Master Ball - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1794489
Net Ball - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1794277
Quick Ball
Heavy Ball
Luxury Ball
Premier Ball
Nest Ball

So check back regularly to get them as they come out and if you have a favourite not on the list let me know and I will try my best to get it designed and made as fast as I can!

PRINTING INSTRUCTIONS

Do not use a raft as parts are not prone to warping and make clean up harder, I do use a brim however to aid adhesion.

Instructions as follows:

Print all parts with support touching build plate.
Remove support, however the PokeBall has been designed to hide all supported surfaces, so they should be hidden from view so a smooth finish is not vital for it to look good.
Print the lids with the dome side up like an igloo.
Print the 'Inner Shells' the other way up like a bowl.
Print the 'Button' with the flat surface on the build plate.
Use 3mm or 1.75mm filament as a hinge pin and shape to fit smoothly as in the pictures so it follows the same curve as the back of the ball.
Do a dry fit of all the parts.
Super glue the lids to their respective 'Inner Shells'.
Place the 'Button' inside the 'Outer Button Smaller' with the two bumps positioned downwards to fit into the 'Inner Shell Bottom' and super glue the 'Outer Button Smaller' to the 'Inner Shell Top' being careful not to glue the 'Inner Button' in place as it must be able to be pressed.
Insert the hinge pin attaching the two halves together and glue in place also taking care not to glue the hinge in a fixed position.
You will need:

1x Lid Bottom Base
1x Lid Top Base
1x Lid Black Top
1x Red Stripes Lower
1x Red Stripes Upper
1x Top Red Stripe
1x Inner Shell Top (choose filament size and with or without support)
1x Inner Shell Bottom (choose filament size and with or without support)
1x Button
1x Outer Button Smaller
1x Stand (optional)
Super Glue
If you have problems with supports or printing let me know and I will do what I can to help. The tolerances are also quite tight as this works on my printer, let me know if you have problems with this.

Happy Printing and Go Catch Them All!

There are two sets here. One is a frame with feet that fit into it. It is big, too big for the Mini to print. But there is another way. Foot_wHole is designed to use one of the screws that hole the base on. It is only 1 mm thick at the top so print at a 0.1 mm layer for strength

Click the photos for better views.
A new design of an old idea. The Dremel Rotary Tool is held securely in the cradle with clamps and 6-32 screws. The cradle is easily adjustable for depth and held to the base with a single one inch long 1/4-20 carriage bolt, flat washer and wingnut. The two knobs are held on with one and a half inch long 1/4-20 carraige bolts into captive nuts in the base. Some of my hardware was the wrong size, so it looks a little funny in the photos. I added flat washers under the knobs because my bolts were a little long.
I can upload the Solidworks 2011 files if anyone wants them.
3-7-2012...Solidworks 2011 files added in the ZIP file.

Print one of each part and a second knob.
Use raft under the cradle. Trim as needed.
Assembly is straightforward. I printed this on my Ronthomp Mendel, but it should print on any Mendel. My router is made with PLA.

title: Improved MP Mini Stock Extruder Arm

description.text:
This extruder lever arm perfectly fits the stock extruder of the monoprice select mini with the only additional part being a 5x11x4 bearing which is readily available locally/online in hobby shops as it is one of the most common rc car bearings (traxxas 5116). The main advantage is the MUCH thicker stronger bearing spindle (5mm vs 2-3mm of the original lever arm).

Installing this arm simply requires the original m3 hex axle bolt and bushing of the original extruder and dropping on the bearing. I originally intended to have a press fit 'cap' over the bearing, but as it turns out the bearing has no tendency to wander upwards anyway.

NOTE : the input hole in the arm has been sized to 4mm ID so that if you wish, you can easily attach/glue/pass through a length of 4mm OD ptfe tubing.

This mermaid is my first experiment with uploading photos to my3dscanner.com to generate a pointcloud.
I was pretty blown away by the results. The undserside of her arm has a little sag, but other than that I feel like the free service did a pretty great job of creating a model from the archive of 40 images I uploaded.

I did my best to clean up the mesh and save it as .STL. The file I uploaded I has been successfully run through replicatorG and previewed in Pleasant3D, so it looks like its good to print. However, I do not yet have access to a 3D printer, so hopefully someone here will give it a try. I'm curious to see how it comes out!

description.text:
This print helps you make battery packs for Neato XV series robot vacuum with AA rechargeable batteries. No soldering required.

Each XV robot vacuum uses 2 battery packs so you'll need to print 2 copies for one machine.

In addition to the print, what you'll need are

  • 12 rechargeable AA batteries (6 for each pack)
  • Wiring or solder tabs for connecting batteries within the pack, 5mm wide solder tabs sold on ebay are recommended.
  • Connectors & temperature sensors for connecting the robot vacuum
    It's best to salvage connectors & sensors from old original battery packs.
  • A couple rubber bands to hold everything together

The original battery pack also has a couple fuses wired between battery cells, but my test shows that it's fine without them.

The packs I made with 2450mah IKEA LADDA batteries last my XV-21 easily over 1 hour of running time. For comparison, the original 3500mah battery packs last about 40 minutes when they were new.

title: Modified Parts Fan Shroud - Max Micron and other Prusa i3

description.text:
Newer version with wire management integrated here - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1803327

Never really liked the stock fan shroud. Just seemed to direct too much air directly at the whole nozzle and heat block making you need higher temps to work the printer. Plus it was big and blocked the view of the nozzle while printing. Have also seen many nice, more directed airflow setups, but they all seem to wrap around and block the nozzle from view.

Designed this one to be a bit tighter up to the carriage, and brought the air flow closer the the actual area being printed, but put a small block in so no air is directed at the nozzle it's self. Went through 3 or 4 designs before I got this final one I like and works really well. (the model images are actually of #3 which was only tweaked for the final which I mounted before taking pictures)

Note- check your layers in the slicer, rotate the model on the bed to get the support material to run front to back over side to side as it's a LOT easier to remove from inside that way.
